option.value: Solving Public Problems with Data - Session 5

slidelink.displaytext: Platforms and Where to Store Data (Total Session Length: 20:24)
Why You Should Care About Data
Two Quotes to Get You Inspired (0:32)
One Figure Worth a Thousand Words (0:54)
Collecting/Creating Data for Our Four Use Cases (0:51)
How to Store and Manipulate the Data
How to Visualize and Publish Data
Using Data to Solve a Public Problem (0:30)

search.slidetext: platforms and where to store data arnaud sahuguet funded by a grant from the www.thegovlab.org
director of the foundry @ cornell tech cto at the governance lab @ nyu product manager @ google bell labs research @sahuguet and i love data. arnaud sahuguet

session outline why you should care about data why you should care about data how to collect/create the data how to represent the data how to store and manipulate the data how to visualize and publish the data
two quotes to get you inspired “in god we trust; everyone else, bring me data.” mike bloomberg, circa 2010 “data is not the plural of anecdote.”

data vs. anecdotes data represents information from either all relevant cases or a representative sample of all the relative cases. inferences made from properly acquired data lead to scientific discoveries. data is scientific. unfortunately, data tends to be dry. it tends to be boring. we generally do not connect emotionally to ‘data.’ anecdotes are stories. people have been telling stories for as long as there has been speech. (…) we empathize with a good storyteller because our ancestors passed on this trait as a survival skill. hence, it literally is natural for us to become emotionally moved by a good story. source
one figure worth a thousand words “a good sketch is better than a long speech.” napoleon bonaparte

four use cases criminal justice incarceration data, crime data, court data, etc. non-profit organizations what they do, how they are rated, tax returns, etc. investigative journalism panama papers, wikileaks, etc. public health pollution data, health records, etc.
four processes collecting data visualizing data manipulating data representing data

collecting/creating data collecting data data already exists data does not exist as open data ➞ download it ➞ scrape it as web pages as scanned pdf ➞ ocr it user data ➞ forms ➞ mobile data collection, e.g. openodk ➞ mobile self-report, e.g. researchkit non-user data ➞ sensors, e.g. iot
some technologies

collecting/creating data for our 4 use cases criminal justice criminal justice criminal justice use existing data sets complement with scraping use existing data sets complement with scraping use existing data sets complement with scraping non-profit organizations non-profit organizations non-profit organizations use existing pdfs, which you might have to ocr scrape websites for auxiliary data surveys use existing pdfs, which you might have to ocr scrape websites for auxiliary data surveys use existing pdfs, which you might have to ocr scrape websites for auxiliary data surveys investigative journalism investigative journalism investigative journalism use wikileaks, etc. use wikileaks, etc. use wikileaks, etc. public health public health public health collect the data, e.g. propeller health collect the data, e.g. propeller health collect the data, e.g. propeller health

representing the data human languages office documents french for poetry italian for opera german for philosophy latin to torture students inuit to talk about snow english for everything else, etc. word document excel spreadsheet powerpoint etc. what’s the best way to represent data? this is the same with data.

representing data representing data raw format as media, e.g. image, video, sound as a text file as a table csv as a tree xml json yaml as a graph rdf n3 other formats timeseries geographic data other

representing our four use cases criminal justice most likely tabular data also text non-profit organizations most likely tabular data but can also be a tree investigative journalism text-data (e.g., email), multimedia data most likely some graph data public health most likely tabular data but also geographic and time series
storing and manipulating data

storing and manipulating data trade-offs storage space & cost efficient access to the data or part of the data operations to run against the data scale of the data (not everything fits in excel) structure of the data

manipulating data manipulating data storing data text files spreadsheet statistical packages relational database nosql database graph database other cleaning data pii password stripping data aggregation/summarization anonymizing data querying data

storing our four use cases criminal justice relational database + text extension non-profit organizations relational database investigative journalism possibly nosql because of size graph database because of structure public health relational database with gis extension + time series
data storage technologies

manipulating data sql sql is a query language to manipulate relational data. this is often the fastest route to get what you want. learning sql is usually a really good investment. sql in a nutshell: everything is a table; a table is made of rows that are made of columns you can project, i.e. dropping some columns you can filter, i.e. dropping some rows based on a predicate you can join tables

sql example select irsein.name as name, irsein.state as state, irsein.city as city, irs990.totrevenue as revenue, irs990.noemplyeesw3cnt as employees, irs990.noindiv100kcnt as employees_over_100k, irs990.compnsatncurrofcr as officers_comp from ‘public-data.irs_990.irs_990_ein’ as irsein join ‘public-data.irs_990.irs_990_2015’ as irs990 using (ein) order by revenue desc source

publishing/visualizing data why publish your data? this is a requirement e.g., freedom of information act in the us requirements from funding agencies you make it accessible to smarter people visualizing data “no matter who you are, most of the smartest people work for someone else.” bill joy, co-founder of sun microsystems
publishing data things to keep in mind size structure license & permission tracking of who is using it cost (storage + download)
options for publishing data consumer open source commercial

visualizing data find the right visualization for your data find the right tool check datavisualization.ch check books by edward tufte lots of free tools. commercial open source for interactive reports, check jupyter notebooks.

visualizing our four use cases criminal justice heatmap timeseries for evolution year by year non-profit organizations pie charts investigative journalism interactive graph public health heatmap dashboard for each user

using data to solve a public problem vision zero is about reducing human casualties in the streets of nyc data is being used to identify where, when, how, and who data is being used to keep track of all initiatives data is being used to measure impact (lives saved + traffic disruptions) data is a key component when solving public problems.

key takeaways don’t settle for anecdotes; get some data. find out if the data already exists; if not, come up with creative ways to collect it. pick a data representation that fits your needs. pick a storage solution that fits your needs. publish your data as open data. pick a visualization that helps you tell your story.
